mn16:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
mn16:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

mn16:1.3.eng: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,

mn16:2.1.pli: “Yassa kassaci, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno pañca cetokhilā appahīnā, pañca cetasovinibandhā asamucchinnā, so vatimasmiṃ dhammavinaye vuddhiṃ virūḷhiṃ vepullaṃ āpajjissatīti—netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjati.
mn16:2.1.eng: “Mendicants, when a mendicant has not given up five kinds of hard-heartedness and severed five shackles of the heart, it’s not possible for them to achieve growth, improvement, or maturity in this teaching and training.
mn16:2.1.comm: The two sets of five are also found at AN 10.14. The five kinds of “hard-heartedness” are also at AN 5.205, AN 9.71, DN 33:2.1.76, and DN 34:1.6.24, and the five “shackles of the heart” are at AN 5.206, AN 9.72, AN 9.82, AN 9.92, and DN 33:2.1.84. | While this sutta is addressed as normal to the bhikkhus, the parallels at AN 10.14, MA 206, and EA 51.4 are all addressed to both monks and nuns. This is one of the instances showing that the term bhikkhu is meant to include both monks and nuns, a common feature of Pali where the default gender is masculine. Hence I translate bhikkhu with “mendicant”, which is both literal and gender-neutral, unless it is clear that males are meant, in which case I use “monk”.

mn16:3.1.eng: What are the five kinds of hard-heartedness they haven’t given up?
mn16:3.1.comm: “Hard-heartedness” or “emotional barrenness” (cetokhila): ceto is one of several words for “mind, heart” and is functionally equivalent to citta, yet it tends to be used in contexts that emphasize the emotional dimensions of the mind such as here. Khila is said, in the commentary to Snp 1.2, to be land so barren that nothing grows even if it rains for four months.

mn16:3.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu satthari kaṅkhati vicikicchati nādhimuccati na sampasīdati.
mn16:3.2.eng: Firstly, a mendicant has doubts about the Teacher. They’re uncertain, undecided, and lacking confidence.

mn16:3.3.pli: Yo so, bhikkhave, bhikkhu satthari kaṅkhati vicikicchati nādhimuccati na sampasīdati tassa cittaṃ na namati ātappāya anuyogāya sātaccāya padhānāya.
mn16:3.3.eng: This being so, their mind doesn’t incline toward keenness, commitment, persistence, and striving.

mn16:3.4.pli: Yassa cittaṃ na namati ātappāya anuyogāya sātaccāya padhānāya, evamassāyaṃ paṭhamo cetokhilo appahīno hoti.
mn16:3.4.eng: This is the first kind of hard-heartedness they haven’t given up.

mn16:4.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu dhamme kaṅkhati vicikicchati nādhimuccati na sampasīdati …pe…
mn16:4.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant has doubts about the teaching …

mn16:4.2.eng: This is the second kind of hard-heartedness.

mn16:5.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu saṅghe kaṅkhati vicikicchati nādhimuccati na sampasīdati …pe…
mn16:5.1.eng: They have doubts about the Saṅgha …

mn16:5.2.eng: This is the third kind of hard-heartedness.

mn16:6.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sikkhāya kaṅkhati vicikicchati nādhimuccati na sampasīdati.
mn16:6.1.eng: They have doubts about the training …
mn16:6.1.comm: While “training” includes the threefold training of ethics, meditation, and wisdom, it specially indicates the foundational training in ethics. This is emphasized in the Chinese parallels, which mention the “precepts” here.

mn16:6.2.pli: Yo so, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sikkhāya kaṅkhati vicikicchati nādhimuccati na sampasīdati, tassa cittaṃ na namati ātappāya anuyogāya sātaccāya padhānāya.

mn16:6.3.pli: Yassa cittaṃ na namati ātappāya anuyogāya sātaccāya padhānāya, evamassāyaṃ catuttho cetokhilo appahīno hoti.
mn16:6.3.eng: This is the fourth kind of hard-heartedness.

mn16:7.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sabrahmacārīsu kupito hoti anattamano āhatacitto khilajāto.
mn16:7.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant is angry and upset with their spiritual companions, resentful and closed off.

mn16:7.2.pli: Yo so, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sabrahmacārīsu kupito hoti anattamano āhatacitto khilajāto, tassa cittaṃ na namati ātappāya anuyogāya sātaccāya padhānāya.
mn16:7.2.eng: This being so, their mind doesn’t incline toward keenness, commitment, persistence, and striving.

mn16:7.3.pli: Yassa cittaṃ na namati ātappāya anuyogāya sātaccāya padhānāya, evamassāyaṃ pañcamo cetokhilo appahīno hoti.
mn16:7.3.eng: This is the fifth kind of hard-heartedness they haven’t given up.

mn16:7.4.eng: These are the five kinds of hard-heartedness they haven’t given up.

mn16:8.1.eng: What are the five shackles of the heart they haven’t severed?

mn16:8.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāme avītarāgo hoti avigatacchando avigatapemo avigatapipāso avigatapariḷāho avigatataṇho.
mn16:8.2.eng: Firstly, a mendicant isn’t free of greed, desire, fondness, thirst, passion, and craving for sensual pleasures.

mn16:8.3.pli: Yo so, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāme avītarāgo hoti avigatacchando avigatapemo avigatapipāso avigatapariḷāho avigatataṇho, tassa cittaṃ na namati ātappāya anuyogāya sātaccāya padhānāya.
mn16:8.3.eng: This being so, their mind doesn’t incline toward keenness, commitment, persistence, and striving.

mn16:8.4.pli: Yassa cittaṃ na namati ātappāya anuyogāya sātaccāya padhānāya, evamassāyaṃ paṭhamo cetasovinibandho asamucchinno hoti.
mn16:8.4.eng: This is the first shackle of the heart they haven’t severed.

mn16:9.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāye avītarāgo hoti …pe…
mn16:9.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant isn’t free of greed for the body …

mn16:9.2.eng: This is the second shackle of the heart.

mn16:10.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu rūpe avītarāgo hoti …pe…
mn16:10.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant isn’t free of greed for form …

mn16:10.2.eng: This is the third shackle of the heart.

mn16:11.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu yāvadatthaṃ udarāvadehakaṃ bhuñjitvā seyyasukhaṃ passasukhaṃ middhasukhaṃ anuyutto viharati.
mn16:11.1.eng: They eat as much as they like until their belly is full, then indulge in the pleasures of sleeping, lying down, and drowsing …

mn16:11.2.pli: Yo so, bhikkhave, bhikkhu yāvadatthaṃ udarāvadehakaṃ bhuñjitvā seyyasukhaṃ passasukhaṃ middhasukhaṃ anuyutto viharati, tassa cittaṃ na namati ātappāya anuyogāya sātaccāya padhānāya.

mn16:11.3.pli: Yassa cittaṃ na namati ātappāya anuyogāya sātaccāya padhānāya, evamassāyaṃ catuttho cetasovinibandho asamucchinno hoti.
mn16:11.3.eng: This is the fourth heart shackle.

mn16:12.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu aññataraṃ devanikāyaṃ paṇidhāya brahmacariyaṃ carati: ‘imināhaṃ sīlena vā vatena vā tapena vā brahmacariyena vā devo vā bhavissāmi devaññataro vā’ti.
mn16:12.1.eng: They lead the spiritual life hoping to be reborn in one of the orders of gods, thinking: ‘By this precept or observance or fervent austerity or spiritual life, may I become one of the gods!’

mn16:12.2.pli: Yo so, bhikkhave, bhikkhu aññataraṃ devanikāyaṃ paṇidhāya brahmacariyaṃ carati: ‘imināhaṃ sīlena vā vatena vā tapena vā brahmacariyena vā devo vā bhavissāmi devaññataro vā’ti, tassa cittaṃ na namati ātappāya anuyogāya sātaccāya padhānāya.
mn16:12.2.eng: This being so, their mind doesn’t incline toward keenness, commitment, persistence, and striving.

mn16:12.3.pli: Yassa cittaṃ na namati ātappāya anuyogāya sātaccāya padhānāya, evamassāyaṃ pañcamo cetasovinibandho asamucchinno hoti.
mn16:12.3.eng: This is the fifth shackle of the heart they haven’t severed.

mn16:12.4.eng: These are the five shackles of the heart they haven’t severed.

mn16:13.1.pli: Yassa kassaci, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno ime pañca cetokhilā appahīnā, ime pañca cetasovinibandhā asamucchinnā, so vatimasmiṃ dhammavinaye vuddhiṃ virūḷhiṃ vepullaṃ āpajjissatīti—netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjati.
mn16:13.1.eng: When a mendicant has not given up these five kinds of hard-heartedness and severed these five shackles of the heart, it’s not possible for them to achieve growth, improvement, or maturity in this teaching and training.

mn16:14.1.pli: Yassa kassaci, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno pañca cetokhilā pahīnā, pañca cetasovinibandhā susamucchinnā, so vatimasmiṃ dhammavinaye vuddhiṃ virūḷhiṃ vepullaṃ āpajjissatīti—ṭhānametaṃ vijjati.
mn16:14.1.eng: When a mendicant has given up these five kinds of hard-heartedness and severed these five shackles of the heart, it is possible for them to achieve growth, improvement, and maturity in this teaching and training.

mn16:15.1.eng: What are the five kinds of hard-heartedness they’ve given up?

mn16:15.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu satthari na kaṅkhati na vicikicchati adhimuccati sampasīdati.
mn16:15.2.eng: Firstly, a mendicant has no doubts about the Teacher. They’re not uncertain, undecided, or lacking confidence.

mn16:15.3.pli: Yo so, bhikkhave, bhikkhu satthari na kaṅkhati na vicikicchati adhimuccati sampasīdati, tassa cittaṃ namati ātappāya anuyogāya sātaccāya padhānāya.
mn16:15.3.eng: This being so, their mind inclines toward keenness, commitment, persistence, and striving.

mn16:15.4.pli: Yassa cittaṃ namati ātappāya anuyogāya sātaccāya padhānāya, evamassāyaṃ paṭhamo cetokhilo pahīno hoti.
mn16:15.4.eng: This is the first kind of hard-heartedness they’ve given up.

mn16:16.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu dhamme na kaṅkhati na vicikicchati adhimuccati sampasīdati …pe…
mn16:16.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant has no doubts about the teaching …

mn16:17.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu saṅghe na kaṅkhati na vicikicchati adhimuccati sampasīdati …pe…
mn16:17.1.eng: They have no doubts about the Saṅgha …

mn16:18.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sikkhāya na kaṅkhati na vicikicchati adhimuccati sampasīdati …pe…
mn16:18.1.eng: They have no doubts about the training …

mn16:19.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sabrahmacārīsu na kupito hoti na anattamano anāhatacitto akhilajāto.
mn16:19.1.eng: They’re not angry and upset with their spiritual companions, not resentful or closed off.

mn16:19.2.pli: Yo so, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sabrahmacārīsu na kupito hoti na anattamano anāhatacitto akhilajāto, tassa cittaṃ namati ātappāya anuyogāya sātaccāya padhānāya.
mn16:19.2.eng: This being so, their mind inclines toward keenness, commitment, persistence, and striving.

mn16:19.3.pli: Yassa cittaṃ namati ātappāya anuyogāya sātaccāya padhānāya, evamassāyaṃ pañcamo cetokhilo pahīno hoti.
mn16:19.3.eng: This is the fifth kind of hard-heartedness they’ve given up.

mn16:19.4.eng: These are the five kinds of hard-heartedness they’ve given up.

mn16:20.1.eng: What are the five shackles of the heart they’ve severed?

mn16:20.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāme vītarāgo hoti vigatacchando vigatapemo vigatapipāso vigatapariḷāho vigatataṇho.
mn16:20.2.eng: Firstly, a mendicant is rid of greed, desire, fondness, thirst, passion, and craving for sensual pleasures.

mn16:20.3.pli: Yo so, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāme vītarāgo hoti vigatacchando vigatapemo vigatapipāso vigatapariḷāho vigatataṇho, tassa cittaṃ namati ātappāya anuyogāya sātaccāya padhānāya.
mn16:20.3.eng: This being so, their mind inclines toward keenness, commitment, persistence, and striving.

mn16:20.4.pli: Yassa cittaṃ namati ātappāya anuyogāya sātaccāya padhānāya, evamassāyaṃ paṭhamo cetasovinibandho susamucchinno hoti.
mn16:20.4.eng: This is the first shackle of the heart they’ve severed.

mn16:21.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāye vītarāgo hoti …pe…
mn16:21.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant is rid of greed for the body …

mn16:22.1.eng: They’re rid of greed for form …

mn16:23.1.pli: na yāvadatthaṃ udarāvadehakaṃ bhuñjitvā seyyasukhaṃ passasukhaṃ middhasukhaṃ anuyutto viharati.
mn16:23.1.eng: They don’t eat as much as they like until their belly is full, then indulge in the pleasures of sleeping, lying down, and drowsing …

mn16:23.2.pli: Yo so, bhikkhave, bhikkhu na yāvadatthaṃ udarāvadehakaṃ bhuñjitvā seyyasukhaṃ passasukhaṃ middhasukhaṃ anuyutto viharati, tassa cittaṃ namati ātappāya anuyogāya sātaccāya padhānāya.

mn16:23.3.pli: Yassa cittaṃ namati ātappāya anuyogāya sātaccāya padhānāya, evamassāyaṃ catuttho cetasovinibandho susamucchinno hoti.

mn16:24.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu na aññataraṃ devanikāyaṃ paṇidhāya brahmacariyaṃ carati: ‘imināhaṃ sīlena vā vatena vā tapena vā brahmacariyena vā devo vā bhavissāmi devaññataro vā’ti.
mn16:24.1.eng: They don’t lead the spiritual life hoping to be reborn in one of the orders of gods, thinking: ‘By this precept or observance or fervent austerity or spiritual life, may I become one of the gods!’

mn16:24.2.pli: Yo so, bhikkhave, bhikkhu na aññataraṃ devanikāyaṃ paṇidhāya brahmacariyaṃ carati: ‘imināhaṃ sīlena vā vatena vā tapena vā brahmacariyena vā devo vā bhavissāmi devaññataro vā’ti, tassa cittaṃ namati ātappāya anuyogāya sātaccāya padhānāya.
mn16:24.2.eng: This being so, their mind inclines toward keenness, commitment, persistence, and striving.

mn16:24.3.pli: Yassa cittaṃ namati ātappāya anuyogāya sātaccāya padhānāya, evamassāyaṃ pañcamo cetasovinibandho susamucchinno hoti.
mn16:24.3.eng: This is the fifth shackle of the heart they’ve severed.

mn16:24.4.eng: These are the five shackles of the heart they’ve severed.

mn16:25.1.pli: Yassa kassaci, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno ime pañca cetokhilā pahīnā, ime pañca cetasovinibandhā susamucchinnā, so vatimasmiṃ dhammavinaye vuddhiṃ virūḷhiṃ vepullaṃ āpajjissatīti—ṭhānametaṃ vijjati.
mn16:25.1.eng: When a mendicant has given up these five kinds of hard-heartedness and severed these five shackles of the heart, it is possible for them to achieve growth, improvement, or maturity in this teaching and training.
mn16:25.1.comm: Up to this point, the discourse is mostly identical to AN 10.14. In the next section, the Buddha goes on to show what “growth” means; with the emotional fundamentals in place, meditation can proceed.

mn16:26.1.eng: They develop the basis of psychic power that has immersion due to enthusiasm, and active effort …
mn16:26.1.comm: The four iddhipada are included in the so-called 37 “wings to awakening” (bodhipakkhiyadhamma). They are an alternate presentation of the path of meditation, with a special focus on developing samādhi. It seems the Buddha designed this presentation of Dhamma to appeal to the many meditators who are fascinated by psychic powers, with the aim to lead them on to the higher goal of liberation. | “Enthusiasm” (chanda) is the desire or will to practice the Dhamma for liberation.

mn16:26.2.eng: the basis of psychic power that has immersion due to energy, and active effort …
mn16:26.2.comm: One who has the requisite enthusiasm will put forth “effort” to achieve the goal.

mn16:26.3.eng: the basis of psychic power that has immersion due to mental development, and active effort …
mn16:26.3.comm: When striving, one will purify and develop the “mind”. When citta appears in meditation contexts, it is often virtually a synonym of samādhi (see eg. cittabhāvanā, cittasampadā).

mn16:26.4.eng: the basis of psychic power that has immersion due to inquiry, and active effort. And the fifth is sheer vigor.
mn16:26.4.comm: The mind clarified in samādhi can investigate the true nature of reality. | Ussoḷhi (“vigor”) is similar in meaning to “energy” (viriya) and “active effort” (saṅkhāra), underscoring the importance of effort here.

mn16:27.1.pli: Sa kho so, bhikkhave, evaṃ ussoḷhipannarasaṅgasamannāgato bhikkhu bhabbo abhinibbidāya, bhabbo sambodhāya, bhabbo anuttarassa yogakkhemassa adhigamāya.
mn16:27.1.eng: A mendicant who possesses these fifteen factors, including vigor, is capable of breaking out, becoming awakened, and reaching the supreme sanctuary from the yoke.
mn16:27.1.comm: Yogakkhema (“sanctuary from the yoke”) is a metaphor for Nibbana that draws from the literal sense of khema as an oasis or sanctuary for men and beasts. After a hard day’s journey, a caravan would stop to rest, “unyoke” the draft animals, lay down the burden, and refresh themselves in the cool waters.

mn16:27.2.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, kukkuṭiyā aṇḍāni aṭṭha vā dasa vā dvādasa vā.
mn16:27.2.eng: Suppose there was a chicken with eight or ten or twelve eggs.
mn16:27.2.comm: This simile recurs at MN 53:19.2 and elsewhere.

mn16:27.3.pli: Tānassu kukkuṭiyā sammā adhisayitāni sammā pariseditāni sammā paribhāvitāni.
mn16:27.3.eng: And she properly sat on them to keep them warm and incubated.

mn16:27.4.pli: Kiñcāpi tassā kukkuṭiyā na evaṃ icchā uppajjeyya:
mn16:27.4.eng: Even if that chicken doesn’t wish:

mn16:27.5.pli: ‘aho vatime kukkuṭapotakā pādanakhasikhāya vā mukhatuṇḍakena vā aṇḍakosaṃ padāletvā sotthinā abhinibbhijjeyyun’ti.
mn16:27.5.eng: ‘If only my chicks could break out of the eggshell with their claws and beak and hatch safely!’

mn16:27.6.pli: Atha kho bhabbāva te kukkuṭapotakā pādanakhasikhāya vā mukhatuṇḍakena vā aṇḍakosaṃ padāletvā sotthinā abhinibbhijjituṃ.
mn16:27.6.eng: Still they can break out and hatch safely.

mn16:27.7.pli: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, evaṃ ussoḷhipannarasaṅgasamannāgato bhikkhu bhabbo abhinibbidāya, bhabbo sambodhāya, bhabbo anuttarassa yogakkhemassa adhigamāyā”ti.
mn16:27.7.eng: In the same way, a mendicant who possesses these fifteen factors, including vigor, is capable of breaking out, becoming awakened, and reaching the supreme sanctuary from the yoke.”

mn16:27.8.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

mn16:27.9.pli: Attamanā te bhikkhū bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinandunti.
mn16:27.9.eng: Satisfied, the mendicants approved what the Buddha said.

mn17:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
mn17:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

mn17:1.3.eng: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,

mn17:2.1.eng: “Mendicants, I will teach you an exposition about jungle thickets.
mn17:2.1.comm: This sutta acts as a counterbalance to the many places where the Buddha encourages living secluded in the forest. The purpose of the life of solitude is to develop meditation and find freedom. But life is complicated and people are complicated, and sometimes what we think will support us becomes a hindrance. So regardless of how secluded and inspiring a place may be, it is crucial to always reflect on one’s actual progress in developing the wholesome.

mn17:2.2.eng: Listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”

mn17:2.3.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho te bhikkhū bhagavato paccassosuṃ.

mn17:3.1.pli: “Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu aññataraṃ vanapatthaṃ upanissāya viharati.
mn17:3.1.eng: “Mendicants, take the case of a mendicant who lives close by a jungle thicket.
mn17:3.1.comm: Here I translate upanissaya as “close by”.

mn17:3.2.pli: Tassa taṃ vanapatthaṃ upanissāya viharato anupaṭṭhitā ceva sati na upaṭṭhāti, asamāhitañca cittaṃ na samādhiyati, aparikkhīṇā ca āsavā na parikkhayaṃ gacchanti, ananuppattañca anuttaraṃ yogakkhemaṃ nānupāpuṇāti.
mn17:3.2.eng: As they do so, their mindfulness does not become established, their mind does not become immersed in samādhi, their defilements do not come to an end, and they do not arrive at the supreme sanctuary from the yoke.
mn17:3.2.comm: This gives a brief summary of the path of meditation. First one “establishes mindfulness”, i.e. undertakes meditation based on the four satipaṭṭhānas. This leads to samādhi as the mind becomes immersed in the four jhānas. Then, seeing reality with the unclouded clarity of a purified mind, defilements are abandoned and one is freed from transmigration.

mn17:3.3.pli: Ye ca kho ime pabbajitena jīvitaparikkhārā samudānetabbā—cīvarapiṇḍapātasenāsanagilānappaccayabhesajjaparikkhārā—te kasirena samudāgacchanti.
mn17:3.3.eng: And the necessities of life that a renunciate requires—robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick—are hard to come by.

mn17:3.5.pli: ‘ahaṃ kho imaṃ vanapatthaṃ upanissāya viharāmi, tassa me imaṃ vanapatthaṃ upanissāya viharato anupaṭṭhitā ceva sati na upaṭṭhāti, asamāhitañca cittaṃ na samādhiyati, aparikkhīṇā ca āsavā na parikkhayaṃ gacchanti, ananuppattañca anuttaraṃ yogakkhemaṃ nānupāpuṇāmi.
mn17:3.5.eng: ‘While living close by this jungle thicket, my mindfulness does not become established, my mind does not become immersed in samādhi, my defilements do not come to an end, and I do not arrive at the supreme sanctuary from the yoke.

mn17:3.6.pli: Ye ca kho ime pabbajitena jīvitaparikkhārā samudānetabbā—cīvarapiṇḍapātasenāsanagilānappaccayabhesajjaparikkhārā—te kasirena samudāgacchantī’ti.
mn17:3.6.eng: And the necessities of life that a renunciate requires—robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick—are hard to come by.’

mn17:3.7.pli: Tena, bhikkhave, bhikkhunā rattibhāgaṃ vā divasabhāgaṃ vā tamhā vanapatthā pakkamitabbaṃ, na vatthabbaṃ.
mn17:3.7.eng: That mendicant should leave that jungle thicket that very time of night or day; they should not stay there.

mn17:4.1.pli: Idha pana, bhikkhave, bhikkhu aññataraṃ vanapatthaṃ upanissāya viharati.
mn17:4.1.eng: Take another case of a mendicant who lives close by a jungle thicket.

mn17:4.2.pli: Tassa taṃ vanapatthaṃ upanissāya viharato anupaṭṭhitā ceva sati na upaṭṭhāti, asamāhitañca cittaṃ na samādhiyati, aparikkhīṇā ca āsavā na parikkhayaṃ gacchanti, ananuppattañca anuttaraṃ yogakkhemaṃ nānupāpuṇāti.
mn17:4.2.eng: Their mindfulness does not become established …

mn17:4.3.pli: Ye ca kho ime pabbajitena jīvitaparikkhārā samudānetabbā—cīvarapiṇḍapātasenāsanagilānappaccayabhesajjaparikkhārā—te appakasirena samudāgacchanti.
mn17:4.3.eng: But the necessities of life are easy to come by.

mn17:4.5.pli: ‘ahaṃ kho imaṃ vanapatthaṃ upanissāya viharāmi. Tassa me imaṃ vanapatthaṃ upanissāya viharato anupaṭṭhitā ceva sati na upaṭṭhāti asamāhitañca cittaṃ na samādhiyati, aparikkhīṇā ca āsavā na parikkhayaṃ gacchanti, ananuppattañca anuttaraṃ yogakkhemaṃ nānupāpuṇāmi.
mn17:4.5.eng: ‘While living close by this jungle thicket, my mindfulness does not become established …

mn17:4.6.pli: Ye ca kho ime pabbajitena jīvitaparikkhārā samudānetabbā—cīvarapiṇḍapātasenāsanagilānappaccayabhesajjaparikkhārā—te appakasirena samudāgacchanti.
mn17:4.6.eng: But the necessities of life are easy to come by.

mn17:4.7.pli: Na kho panāhaṃ cīvarahetu agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito na piṇḍapātahetu …pe… na senāsanahetu …pe… na gilānappaccayabhesajjaparikkhārahetu agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito.
mn17:4.7.eng: But I didn’t go forth from the lay life to homelessness for the sake of a robe, almsfood, lodgings, or medicines and supplies for the sick.

mn17:4.8.pli: Atha ca pana me imaṃ vanapatthaṃ upanissāya viharato anupaṭṭhitā ceva sati na upaṭṭhāti, asamāhitañca cittaṃ na samādhiyati, aparikkhīṇā ca āsavā na parikkhayaṃ gacchanti, ananuppattañca anuttaraṃ yogakkhemaṃ nānupāpuṇāmī’ti.
mn17:4.8.eng: Moreover, while living close by this jungle thicket, my mindfulness does not become established …’

mn17:4.9.pli: Tena, bhikkhave, bhikkhunā saṅkhāpi tamhā vanapatthā pakkamitabbaṃ, na vatthabbaṃ.
mn17:4.9.eng: That mendicant should, after appraisal, leave that jungle thicket; they should not stay there.
mn17:4.9.comm: In this case they should leave after reflection, not necessarily “that very day”, since at least they can live comfortably and healthily, which is no small thing.

mn17:5.3.eng: But the necessities of life that a renunciate requires—robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick—are hard to come by. That mendicant should reflect:

mn17:5.5.pli: Tassa me imaṃ vanapatthaṃ upanissāya viharato anupaṭṭhitā ceva sati upaṭṭhāti asamāhitañca cittaṃ samādhiyati, aparikkhīṇā ca āsavā parikkhayaṃ gacchanti, ananuppattañca anuttaraṃ yogakkhemaṃ anupāpuṇāmi.
mn17:5.5.eng: ‘While living close by this jungle thicket, my mindfulness becomes established …

mn17:5.6.pli: Ye ca kho ime pabbajitena jīvitaparikkhārā samudānetabbā—cīvarapiṇḍapātasenāsanagilānappaccayabhesajjaparikkhārā—te kasirena samudāgacchanti.
mn17:5.6.eng: But the necessities of life are hard to come by.

mn17:5.7.pli: Na kho panāhaṃ cīvarahetu agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito, na piṇḍapātahetu …pe… na senāsanahetu …pe… na gilānappaccayabhesajjaparikkhārahetu agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito.
mn17:5.7.eng: But I didn’t go forth from the lay life to homelessness for the sake of a robe, almsfood, lodgings, or medicines and supplies for the sick.

mn17:5.8.pli: Atha ca pana me imaṃ vanapatthaṃ upanissāya viharato anupaṭṭhitā ceva sati upaṭṭhāti, asamāhitañca cittaṃ samādhiyati, aparikkhīṇā ca āsavā parikkhayaṃ gacchanti, ananuppattañca anuttaraṃ yogakkhemaṃ anupāpuṇāmī’ti.
mn17:5.8.eng: Moreover, while living close by this jungle thicket, my mindfulness becomes established …’

mn17:5.9.pli: Tena, bhikkhave, bhikkhunā saṅkhāpi tasmiṃ vanapatthe vatthabbaṃ, na pakkamitabbaṃ.
mn17:5.9.eng: That mendicant should, after appraisal, stay in that jungle thicket; they should not leave.
mn17:5.9.comm: Even if life is hard, meditation progress is more important.

mn17:6.1.pli: Idha pana, bhikkhave, bhikkhu aññataraṃ vanapatthaṃ upanissāya viharati.

mn17:6.6.eng: And the necessities of life are easy to come by.’

mn17:6.7.eng: That mendicant should stay in that jungle thicket for the rest of their life; they should not leave.

mn17:7-10.1.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu aññataraṃ gāmaṃ upanissāya viharati …pe…
mn17:7-10.1.eng: Take the case of a mendicant who lives supported by a village …
mn17:7-10.1.comm: In the remaining cases I translate upanissaya as “supported by”.

mn17:23.2.pli: Tassa taṃ puggalaṃ upanissāya viharato anupaṭṭhitā ceva sati na upaṭṭhāti, asamāhitañca cittaṃ na samādhiyati, aparikkhīṇā ca āsavā na parikkhayaṃ gacchanti, ananuppattañca anuttaraṃ yogakkhemaṃ nānupāpuṇāti.
mn17:23.2.eng: As they do so, their mindfulness does not become established, their mind does not become immersed in samādhi, their defilements do not come to an end, and they do not arrive at the supreme sanctuary from the yoke.

mn17:23.3.pli: Ye ca kho ime pabbajitena jīvitaparikkhārā samudānetabbā—cīvarapiṇḍapātasenāsanagilānappaccayabhesajjaparikkhārā—te kasirena samudāgacchanti.
mn17:23.3.eng: And the necessities of life that a renunciate requires—robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick—are hard to come by.

mn17:23.5.pli: ‘ahaṃ kho imaṃ puggalaṃ upanissāya viharāmi. Tassa me imaṃ puggalaṃ upanissāya viharato anupaṭṭhitā ceva sati na upaṭṭhāti, asamāhitañca cittaṃ na samādhiyati, aparikkhīṇā ca āsavā na parikkhayaṃ gacchanti, ananuppattañca anuttaraṃ yogakkhemaṃ nānupāpuṇāmi.
mn17:23.5.eng: ‘… my mindfulness does not become established …

mn17:23.6.pli: Ye ca kho ime pabbajitena jīvitaparikkhārā samudānetabbā—cīvarapiṇḍapātasenāsanagilānappaccayabhesajjaparikkhārā—te kasirena samudāgacchantī’ti.
mn17:23.6.eng: And the necessities of life are hard to come by.’

mn17:23.7.pli: Tena, bhikkhave, bhikkhunā rattibhāgaṃ vā divasabhāgaṃ vā so puggalo anāpucchā pakkamitabbaṃ, nānubandhitabbo.
mn17:23.7.eng: That mendicant should leave that individual at any time of the day or night, without taking leave; they should not follow them. …
mn17:23.7.comm: The mendicant’s supporters have not fulfilled their duty to provide adequate requisites, so the mendicant is not obliged to take leave from them.

mn17:24.6.eng: But the necessities of life are easy to come by.’ …

mn17:24.9.eng: That mendicant should, after appraisal, leave that individual having taken leave; they should not follow them. …

mn17:25.3.pli: Ye ca kho ime pabbajitena jīvitaparikkhārā samudānetabbā—cīvarapiṇḍapātasenāsanagilānappaccayabhesajjaparikkhārā—te kasirena samudāgacchanti.
mn17:25.3.eng: But the necessities of life are hard to come by.

mn17:25.5.pli: ‘ahaṃ kho imaṃ puggalaṃ upanissāya viharāmi. Tassa me imaṃ puggalaṃ upanissāya viharato anupaṭṭhitā ceva sati upaṭṭhāti, asamāhitañca cittaṃ samādhiyati, aparikkhīṇā ca āsavā parikkhayaṃ gacchanti, ananuppattañca anuttaraṃ yogakkhemaṃ anupāpuṇāmi.

mn17:25.6.pli: Ye ca kho ime pabbajitena jīvitaparikkhārā samudānetabbā—cīvarapiṇḍapātasenāsanagilānappaccayabhesajjaparikkhārā—te kasirena samudāgacchanti.
mn17:25.6.eng: But the necessities of life are hard to come by.’ …

mn17:25.7.pli: Na kho panāhaṃ cīvarahetu agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito, na piṇḍapātahetu …pe… na senāsanahetu …pe… na gilānappaccayabhesajjaparikkhārahetu agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito.

mn17:25.8.pli: Atha ca pana me imaṃ puggalaṃ upanissāya viharato anupaṭṭhitā ceva sati upaṭṭhāti, asamāhitañca cittaṃ samādhiyati, aparikkhīṇā ca āsavā parikkhayaṃ gacchanti, ananuppattañca anuttaraṃ yogakkhemaṃ anupāpuṇāmī’ti.

mn17:25.9.eng: That mendicant should, after appraisal, follow that individual; they should not leave.

mn17:26.1.pli: Idha pana, bhikkhave, bhikkhu aññataraṃ puggalaṃ upanissāya viharati.
mn17:26.1.eng: Take another case of a mendicant who lives supported by an individual.

mn17:26.2.pli: Tassa taṃ puggalaṃ upanissāya viharato anupaṭṭhitā ceva sati upaṭṭhāti, asamāhitañca cittaṃ samādhiyati, aparikkhīṇā ca āsavā parikkhayaṃ gacchanti, ananuppattañca anuttaraṃ yogakkhemaṃ anupāpuṇāti.
mn17:26.2.eng: As they do so, their mindfulness becomes established, their mind becomes immersed in samādhi, their defilements come to an end, and they arrive at the supreme sanctuary from the yoke.

mn17:26.3.pli: Ye ca kho ime pabbajitena jīvitaparikkhārā samudānetabbā—cīvarapiṇḍapātasenāsanagilānappaccayabhesajjaparikkhārā—te appakasirena samudāgacchanti.
mn17:26.3.eng: And the necessities of life that a renunciate requires—robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick—are easy to come by.

mn17:26.5.pli: ‘ahaṃ kho imaṃ puggalaṃ upanissāya viharāmi. Tassa me imaṃ puggalaṃ upanissāya viharato anupaṭṭhitā ceva sati upaṭṭhāti, asamāhitañca cittaṃ samādhiyati, aparikkhīṇā ca āsavā parikkhayaṃ gacchanti, ananuppattañca anuttaraṃ yogakkhemaṃ anupāpuṇāmi.
mn17:26.5.eng: ‘While living supported by this individual, my mindfulness becomes established …

mn17:26.6.pli: Ye ca kho ime pabbajitena jīvitaparikkhārā samudānetabbā—cīvarapiṇḍapātasenāsanagilānappaccayabhesajjaparikkhārā—te appakasirena samudāgacchantī’ti.
mn17:26.6.eng: And the necessities of life are easy to come by.’

mn17:26.7.pli: Tena, bhikkhave, bhikkhunā yāvajīvampi so puggalo anubandhitabbo, na pakkamitabbaṃ, api panujjamānenapī”ti.
mn17:26.7.eng: That mendicant should follow that individual for the rest of their life; they should not leave them, even if driven away.”
mn17:26.7.comm: The idiom “even if driven away” (api panujjamānena) occurs a few times in this sense (MN 122:19.2, AN 7.37:1.1, AN 9.6:6.4).

mn17:26.8.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

mn17:26.9.pli: Attamanā te bhikkhū bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinandunti.
mn17:26.9.eng: Satisfied, the mendicants approved what the Buddha said.
